title-group.article-title: Jump On It! The Association of Physical Therapy Timing and Frequency With Functional Outcomes in Patients Supported With Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation: A Single-Center Retrospective Study

contrib-group.aff: 1 Department of Anesthesiology, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA.
2 Department of Emergency Medicine, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA.
3 Emory Critical Care Center, Atlanta, GA.
4 Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, Division of Physical Therapy, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA.
5 Department of Physical Therapy, Ivester College of Health Sciences, Brenau University, Gainesville, GA.

sec.title: IMPORTANCE:
sec.p: Physical therapy (PT) interventions for patients supported with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is thought to help preserve independence, but the impact of PT frequency on ECMO recovery is not well understood.

sec.title: OBJECTIVES:
sec.p: To explore the relationship between PT frequency and functional outcomes in patients supported with ECMO.

sec.title: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS:
sec.p: Retrospective, single-center study of patients supported with ECMO at a large volume ECMO referral center. Patients were grouped by PT frequency (high < 3 d, moderate 3–7 d, and low > 7 d between sessions).

sec.title: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES:
sec.p: The primary outcome was the final Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) “6-Clicks” Basic Mobility Score. For the subgroup of patients discharged alive, a multivariable logistic model was used to understand what affected a patient’s odds of a final AM-PAC score greater than or equal to 18, indicating functional independence.

sec.title: RESULTS:
sec.p: One hundred forty-two subjects were included with a median age of 48 years (interquartile range, 35–58 yr). Patients received venovenous (55%, n = 78/142) or venoarterial (45%, n = 64/142) ECMO. Of the cohort, 61% (n = 86/142) were discharged alive. A final AM-PAC score of greater than or equal to 18 was seen in 30% of patients (n = 43/142) before discharge. High- and moderate-frequency groups were more likely to survive to hospital discharge (76%, n = 22/29 and 75%, n = 38/51 vs. 44%, n = 27/62; p = 0.001). Controlling for age, sex, PT frequency, and the number of PT sessions after ECMO, logistic regression showed the number of PT sessions on ECMO (odds ratio, 1.13; 95% CI, 1.02–1.28) significantly impacted the odds of a final AM-PAC score greater than or equal to 18.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE:
sec.p: In patients supported with ECMO, high- and moderate-frequency of PT and PT on ECMO were associated with improved functional outcomes at hospital discharge.

sec.title: KEY POINTS
sec.p: Question: Is there an association between the frequency of physical therapy and functional outcomes in patients supported with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)?

Findings: In this single-center retrospective study of 142 patients supported with ECMO, participation in high- and moderate-frequency physical therapy during hospitalization was associated with improved function upon hospital discharge. Additionally, physical therapy on ECMO was associated with an increased odds of being discharged with an AM-PAC score of 18 or more.
Meaning: High- and moderate-frequency physical therapy during or after ECMO support, as well as physical therapy on ECMO, is associated with improved functional outcomes at hospital discharge.

body.p: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a form of organ support for patients with severe cardiorespiratory failure that is becoming more common (1). Venovenous and venoarterial ECMO are used for primary respiratory and cardiac pathologies, respectively (2). Patients requiring either venoarterial or venovenous ECMO are at significant risk for ICU-acquired weakness (ICU-AW), with prior studies demonstrating that 67–80% of patients develop ICU-AW and significant muscle wasting can occur in under a week from initiation of ECMO support (1, 3, 4). Examination and intervention by a physical therapist and early mobilization of all ICU patients is recommended by the Society of Critical Care Medicine as safe and effective ways to minimize the effects of ICU-AW (5). Patient mobility on ECMO has been previously limited due to safety concerns, leading to increased immobilization compared with non-ECMO patients, which results in higher rates of ICU-AW (1, 6). Ambulation, intensive rehabilitation, and nutritional support during ECMO can lead to improved patient outcomes, including enhanced functional mobility and independence (7–9).

ICU-AW is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness that commences as early as 5 days after ICU admission in up to 50% of ICU patients, with increased prevalence in surgical ICUs and in geriatric patient populations (10–12). Sedation practices, neuromuscular blockade (NMB) use, and individual ICU culture leading to immobility impact the ability to initiate physical therapy (PT) in patients requiring ECMO (1, 5, 13). The long-term sequela of ICU-AW include decreased physical and cognitive functioning, the need for increased rehabilitation after hospital discharge, decreased health-related quality of life, and increased caregiver burden (1, 3, 4). PT interventions, including exercise, mobility, and ambulation while on all types of ECMO, have been demonstrated to be efficacious and safe with a low incidence of adverse events (7). Furthermore, adverse effects of mobility on ECMO, such as oxygen desaturation, cannulation complications, and hemodynamic instability, tend to be infrequent and unlikely to impact survival or clinical course (7).

Increased activity and the ability to achieve higher levels of mobility, such as standing and ambulating while on ECMO, have been associated with improved survival and discharge destination (14). For patients acutely experiencing and recovering from critical illness, rehabilitation and optimal discharge planning are essential to facilitate an improved quality of life and a return to independence (15). This study aimed to investigate the association between the timing of PT intervention (on ECMO or after decannulation) and the frequency of PT intervention with functional status, survival, and discharge destination in patients supported with ECMO during their hospitalization.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p: This was a single-center retrospective study of all patients cannulated for ECMO between January 1, 2021, and December 31, 2021, at a high-volume ECMO center. Institutional Review Board approved this study No. 00004012, approval date March 26, 2022) and all research procedures were followed in accordance with the ethical standards of the committee and with the Helsinki Declaration of 1975. Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology and REporting of studies Conducted using Observational Routinely-collected health Data guidelines for reporting observational data were followed (16).

sec.title: Study Site
sec.p: The study site has a well-established multidisciplinary ECMO program that includes physicians, advanced practice providers, nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, respiratory therapists, ECMO specialists, and perfusionists. Awake ECMO and extubating patients while on ECMO are common practices within this unit. The typical practice dictates daily spontaneous awakening trials and minimizing sedation to the lowest degree tolerated by the patient in alignment with the ABCDE Bundle. Spontaneous awakening trials are typically initiated on the day of cannulation and after arrival to the hospital if cannulated elsewhere, pending clinical stability as determined by the treating Critical Care Physician. Additionally, enteral nutrition is usually started within the first 24 hours with guidance from dietitians, as long as patients are generally stable and have decreasing vasoactive requirements. The standard venovenous ECMO configuration used was a right femoral vein drainage cannula and a right internal jugular vein return cannula. The standard venoarterial ECMO configuration consisted of a right femoral vein drainage cannula, a left common femoral artery return cannula, and a left superficial femoral artery distal perfusion catheter. Left ventricular offloading was dictated by individual patient characteristics and was done either with an Impella device (Abiomed, Danvers, MA) or with an intra-aortic balloon pump.

sec.title: Patient Selection
sec.p: Institutional quality assurance programs track data for every patient cannulated and initiated on ECMO. This information was used to identify all patients cannulated for ECMO during 2021. Patients in the cohort were supported by venovenous ECMO or venoarterial ECMO and were included if they were at least 18 years old and received ECMO support for at least 3 days. Those patients on ECMO for less than 3 days were excluded as it was determined that they would not have time to be evaluated for and participate in PT while on ECMO. Patients who had more than one period on ECMO during their hospitalization were also excluded. Patients included in this study were cannulated for ECMO within the study institution, by a referring facility, or remotely cannulated by the study institution’s ECMO team at the referring facility.

sec.title: Physical Therapy Evaluation
sec.p: The institutional practice for PT evaluation of ECMO patients involves a daily review of all cardiovascular ICU patients with the multidisciplinary team to assess each patient for medical stability and the suitability of PT, considering their mental status, ability to engage in therapy, and timeline for other planned procedural or operative interventions.

Patients deemed appropriate for a PT evaluation would undergo an in-bed PT evaluation for range of motion, manual muscle test, and a bed-level functional mobility assessment. If patients remained clinically stable and tolerated the initial evaluation, they would progress to an edge-of-bed assessment, a standing assessment, and an ambulation assessment. Depending on patient performance, these assessments could occur within a single PT session or during subsequent sessions. Patients not considered appropriate for advancing to ambulation would be given a goal of receiving PT 6 days a week for a 2-week time period until they were either able to ambulate, or a reassessment of appropriate functional goals was needed. Patients unable to ambulate after the 2-week 6 days per week intensive trial, had a frequency then set at 5 days per week to accommodate a slower recovery timeline. Patients who could ambulate were given a PT frequency of six times per week. The entire support team available for ambulation assistance included a physical therapist, an ECMO specialist or perfusionist, a respiratory therapist as needed for mechanical ventilation or high-flow oxygenation, and the patient’s primary nurse. A detailed and stepwise approach to PT consultation and initiation (Supplement 1, Fig. S1.1, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539), progression of PT intensity (S1.2, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539), criteria for ambulation (S1.3, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539), and safety measures (S1.4, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539) can be found in the Supplement (https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539).

sec.title: Variables
sec.p: The primary measure in this study was the Boston University “6-Clicks” Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) Basic Mobility short form score. The AM-PAC assesses a patient’s functional mobility, rehabilitation prognosis, and discharge disposition (17). The AM-PAC encompasses six skills scored 1–4, representing total assistance by a therapist to the absence of assistance. The six areas scored are a patient’s ability to roll, transfer supine to sit, transfer sit to stand, transfer bed to chair, ambulate, and climb stairs. Patients with an AM-PAC score of 16 or greater have a higher incidence of discharge to home (18). The AM-PAC score has demonstrated high interrater reliability across surgical, medical, and neurologic ICUs (19, 20).

AM-PAC scores were retroactively determined based on mobility tasks that were documented during PT encounters. Data collectors were trained in the use of a standardized algorithm to interpret objectively documented information and codify AM-PAC scores. Scores were based on the exact activities listed and the assistance amounts listed within the PT notes. If an activity was not documented, it was either given the score of the next higher level of mobility or scored a 1 if there was no higher level of mobility documented. Further description of AM-PAC scoring can be seen in Supplement 2.2 (https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). Additional variables included the number of PT sessions during hospitalization, the number of PT sessions while on ECMO, and complications that occurred during those sessions. The frequency of PT sessions was calculated to understand the longitudinal PT exposure for each patient. The number of PT sessions on or after ECMO was divided by the number of days from ECMO cannulation to hospital discharge. Patients were then grouped by frequency of PT, which correlated with days between PT sessions (high < 3 d, moderate 3–7 d, and low > 7 d). If a patient did not receive PT, their frequency was calculated based on the number of days from cannulation to discharge. Therefore, a patient who did not receive PT and had a time from cannulation to discharge of 30 days would have a frequency of 30, placing them in the low-frequency group.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The primary outcome of this study was functional status at discharge as measured by the Boston University “6-Clicks” AM-PAC Basic Mobility short form (20–22). This was dichotomized into greater than or equal to 18 or less than 18 to separate patients who could independently walk at least ten steps at discharge (Fig. S2.1, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). Outcomes included survival to hospital discharge and discharge destination. Safety data was collected to include complications that occurred during each PT session.

sec.title: Data Extraction
sec.p: Trained reviewers extracted patient data from the medical record using a standard extraction guide and data dictionary. After initial data extraction, a random sample of charts was subsequently checked for accuracy by a second reviewer. A third reviewer corrected any discrepancies for data integrity. Data encompassed clinical interventions, ECMO type, ICU interventions, mechanical circulatory support device (Balloon pump or Impella device), diagnoses, number of PT sessions, AM-PAC score before ECMO, first AM-PAC score on ECMO, last AM-PAC score on ECMO, initial AM-PAC score after decannulation, final in-patient AM-PAC score, reason for ECMO discontinuation, discharge disposition, level of therapy needed at discharge, and in-hospital mortality. Cannulation site data and etiology of illness leading to ECMO support were only available for patients supported with venovenous ECMO. Etiologies of venoarterial ECMO were not available due to limitations with the local registry data.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: Summary statistics were calculated using medians and proportions. Group comparisons were completed by Mann-Whitney U, Fisher exact, or chi-square tests, as appropriate. To address confounding by illness severity, only the population that survived to hospital discharge was used for modeling. A logistic Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO) regression model with ten-fold cross-validation was used to understand which factors affect a patient’s functional status at discharge. The outcome for the model was an AM-PAC greater than or equal to 18 or an AM-PAC less than 18 to align with a patient being safe for discharge home. Briefly, LASSO regression seeks to find the most parsimonious model by selecting only those variables that contribute the most to the model’s performance, which is beneficial for datasets with large numbers of variables. Before cross-validation, the data were divided 80/20 into a derivation and validation cohort, with the outcome of interest being equally divided between the two cohorts. Penalty values for the LASSO regression were chosen after tuning the model with a grid of possible penalty values. The penalty value was then optimized to allow for the smallest model with negligible change in model performance. A final multivariable logistic model was created using the results of the LASSO regression and expert consensus for final variable selection. All included variables were checked for collinearity and interactions. Ordinal logistic regression was also attempted, but the proportional odds assumption was violated, so that method was not used. Information about missingness can be seen in Table S4 (https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). Data that were missing were not imputed in any way. Summary statistics included all patients with missing data treated as a null value. Only patients with complete data were used for modeling. All analyses were completed in R, Version 4.4.0 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria; https://www.R-project.org/).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: During the study period, 159 patients were supported with ECMO and 142 met the inclusion criteria (Fig. S3, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). The cohort of patients was predominantly male (64%, n = 91/142), with a median age of 48 years (interquartile range [IQR], 35–58 yr). Most patients were discharged alive (61%, n = 86/142), of which 50% (n = 43/86) were discharged directly to their home. Venovenous ECMO (55%, 78/142) was more common than venoarterial ECMO (45%, n = 64/142), and 43% (n = 61/142) of patients were diagnosed with COVID-19. Patients spent a median of 11 days (IQR, 6–23 d) on ECMO. The median ICU length of stay was 27 days (IQR, 17–47 d). Further patient characteristics can be seen in Table 1. The etiology of illness leading to venovenous ECMO support was primarily viral (74%, n = 58/78) with non-acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) etiologies (i.e., asthma, inhalation, or tracheal injury) making up 14% (11/78) of venovenous ECMO cases.

caption.p: Patient Characteristics by Physical Therapy Exposure

fn.label: a
fn.p: ECMO Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Pearson χ2 test, and Fisher exact test.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Bridge to: heart transplant (n = 1), lung transplant (n = 3), and left ventricular assist device (n = 2).

fn.label: c
fn.p: Care withdrawn/died vs. (recovery + bridge to treatment).
Data are presented as median (interquartile range) or n (%).

sec.title: Physical Therapy Outcomes
sec.p: Overall, most patients (67%, n = 95/142) participated in PT interventions either while on ECMO or after decannulation from ECMO. PT interventions were associated with an increased proportion of patients surviving to hospital discharge and being discharged directly home (Table 1). Patients were also more likely to be discharged alive if they received PT on ECMO (74%, n = 32/43 vs. 56%, n = 55/99; p = 0.03). Patients who did not participate in PT were more likely to be supported with venoarterial ECMO (62%, n = 29/47 vs. 37%, n = 35/95; p = 0.01) and had a higher mortality rate (85%, n = 40/47 vs. 17%, n = 16/95; p < 0.001). The final AM-PAC score was greater than or equal to 18 for 45% patients (n = 43/95) who received PT.

Of the patients who participated in PT, 45% (n = 43/95) participated while on ECMO, and 85% (n = 81/95) after decannulation from ECMO (Table 2). Among patients who participated in PT, the most common discharge location from the hospital was home (39% n = 37/95), followed by acute rehabilitation (20%, n = 19/95), and long-term acute care facility (16%, n = 15/95).

caption.p: Patients Who Received Physical Therapy Stratified by Type of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation

fn.p: AM-PAC = Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care, ECMO = extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, PT = physical therapy.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Mann-Whitney U test, Fisher exact test, and Pearson χ2 test.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Care withdrawn/died vs. (recover and bridge to treatment).

fn.label: c
fn.p: Home vs. acute rehabilitation vs. expired vs. other.
Data are presented as median (interquartile range) or n (%).

sec.p: When considering PT intervention frequency, there were more frequent PT sessions among those patients who survived to hospital discharge (Fig. 1; p = 0.017; Mann-Whitney U test). Stratifying patients into high-, medium-, and low-frequency PT groups, the high- and medium-frequency groups showed greater improvement in AM-PAC score (Fig. 2; and Table S5.1, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). There was no difference between high- and medium-frequency PT in regard to the change in AM-PAC score from the initial to the final AM-PAC scores. More patients in the high-frequency group were bridged to definitive long-term treatment such as transplantation (high 23%, n = 5/22 vs. medium 2.7%, n = 1/37; p = 0.02). Additionally, the high-frequency group received PT more often while on ECMO (Table S5.2, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539).

caption.p: Survival among extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) patients who received physical therapy (PT) and frequency of PT. Those who received PT more frequently were significantly more likely to survive with a median of 4.5 d between PT (interquartile range [IQR], 2.0–7.0 d) compared with those who died, median of 5.7 d (IQR, 3.0–8.2 d; p = 0.017, Mann-Whitney U test). The rectangles of the box plot represent the Q1, median, and Q3 of the data while circles beyond the whisker lines reflect outliers. VA = venoarterial, VV = venovenous.

Initial and final Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) scores grouped by physical therapy (PT) frequency. Change in AM-PAC from initial to final high 7 (interquartile range, 3–11) vs. low 2 (0–7; p = 0.047), medium 8 (4–12) vs. low 2 (0–7; p = 0.004; and Table S5.2, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). PT frequency was calculated by dividing the number of PT sessions on or after extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) by the number of days from ECMO cannulation to hospital discharge. For patients who did not receive PT, their frequency was set to the number of days from cannulation to discharge. The frequency was categorized as high (< 3 d), moderate (3–7 d), or low (> 7 d).

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: Among 1201 PT sessions, 579 sessions (48%) occurred with patients supported with ECMO and 622 sessions (52%) after cessation of ECMO therapy. Patients had a median of 7 (IQR, 4–13) sessions during hospitalization. Complications of any severity occurred during only 7.4% (n = 43) of ECMO mobility sessions, representing 20 different patients (47%, 20/43). The most common complication seen was bradyarrhythmias (n = 12), which were quickly mitigated and did not result in termination of the PT session. Notably, eight of the 12 bradyarrhythmia events were attributed to the same patient, who underwent pacemaker implantation during their ECMO course. Specific ECMO-related complications occurred in six (1%, n = 6/579) of all ECMO sessions and only one session had to be stopped due to changes in ECMO flow. These complications were due to minor, manageable ECMO flow changes and were not clinically significant. Patient falls or injuries did not occur in any PT sessions. Complete complication data are presented in Table S5.3 (https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). Patients supported with venovenous ECMO were cannulated almost exclusively via a femoral drainage cannula (99%, n = 77/78) and an internal jugular return cannula (79%, n = 62/78; and Table S5.4, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539).

sec.title: Patients Who Survived to Hospital Discharge
sec.p: Among patients who survived to hospital discharge (61%, n = 86/142), no difference was noted in final AM-PAC scores or the change in AM-PAC scores from initial to final (Table S5.5, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). To understand which clinical factors impacted patients’ functional status at discharge, a logistic regression model was conducted on this subgroup of patients who were discharged alive from the hospital. The final model included 67 patients discharged alive with complete data and showed that the number of PT sessions on ECMO (odds ratio, 1.13 [1.02–1.28]) was associated with an increased odds of being discharged with an AM-PAC greater than or equal to 18 (Fig. 3). This effect was consistent in sensitivity analysis containing all patients and patients who received PT (Table S5.6, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539).

caption.p: Forest plot of multivariable logistic regression for a final Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) score greater than or equal to 18 among patients discharged alive. ECMO = extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This retrospective study of adult patients supported on ECMO and receiving PT at various times and frequencies during hospitalization found an association between moderate or high-frequency PT and improved function upon hospital discharge. Additionally, modeling showed an association with PT on ECMO and increased odds of being discharged with an AM-PAC score greater than or equal to 18.

Our results expand those in a recent systematic review by Rivera et al. (23) examining the benefits, risks and efficacy of physical rehabilitation and/or mobilization in patients on ECMO. Our study offers more granular data on mobilization protocols and the functional status of patients studied. Additionally, it provides information regarding site-specific ECMO volume, rehabilitation team infrastructure, and patient-specific outcomes such as functional status and discharge destination. Consistent with other comparably designed studies, ours showed an association between PT interventions, including exercise, mobility, and ambulation, both during and after ECMO, and improved functional status at discharge. Associations with improved survival rates were additionally identified, as noted in prior work (14). Other protocols addressing patient candidacy for PT on ECMO vary significantly in their criteria. Often in other published protocols, only 50% of patients or fewer will meet criteria to initiate a PT evaluation (3, 23).

Within our cohort, AM-PAC scores increased from initial to final assessment in all frequency subgroups; however, the highest rate of change was noted in the high- and medium-frequency PT groups. Those in the high-frequency PT intervention group were more frequently patients on ECMO as a bridge to treatment (BTT; transplant, or other treatment strategy such as surgical left ventricular assist device [LVAD]) and furthermore, were more likely to participate in PT while on ECMO. Although a bias in referral is possible (i.e., patients potentially needing a transplant or LVAD were increasingly likely to be referred to PT for mandatory preoperative conditioning and optimization), it could be that these same patients may have been relatively more stable compared with those who did not meet criteria for BTT based on severity of illness. Only six patients out of the 86 discharged alive in this study were classified as BTT. To avoid referral biases, some ECMO centers have reported an automatic consult placed on day 2 of ECMO support to ensure chart review and team discussion to avoid overlooking patients who may be candidates for PT intervention (14).

In terms of safety, no PT sessions on ECMO had clinically significant and/or serious complications, and only one session-required cessation of the PT session due to ECMO flow changes. Our findings are broadly consistent with adverse event reports in similar studies, which quote occurrence in 0–0.001% of sessions (7, 8, 24). Overall, major events discussed in other studies include stroke, pulmonary embolism, arrhythmias (0.5–5%), tachypnea (3%) and limited distal reperfusion cannula bleeding (0.05–20%) (7, 8, 24, 25). The most common complication in our cohort was bradyarrhythmias, the predominance of which occurred in one individual until undergoing pacemaker placement. Overall, this is yet another demonstration of the safety and feasibility of assertive and functionally impactful PT. In preparation for mobilization, several steps were taken to ensure safety, including catheter grip devices, suture placement, and cannula position checks before and after each session; as well as the participation of a multidisciplinary team including a physical therapist, nurse, and perfusionist or ECMO specialist (S1.1–S1.4, https://links.lww.com/CCX/B539). Complications associated with ECMO mobility are inconsistently documented in the literature; however, the complications reported here provide a clear understanding of the limited risks that occur during closely monitored patient mobilization while on ECMO.

PT session frequency was also associated with survival, but these results should be interpreted cautiously. Meeting candidacy for initiation of PT and factors, such as severity of illness, limiting sedation, or exposure to paralytics, could play a significant role in improving survival beyond PT. While our study did not look specifically at patient sedation, the impact of prolonged sedation on increased rates of ICU-AW cannot be overstated. Similarly, deconditioning due to the duration of immobility, inadequate nutrition, and the neuromuscular effects of sedation and NMB, should be appreciated (5). Although early rehabilitation has been demonstrated to improve outcomes in critically ill patients with various diagnoses, venovenous ECMO is frequently used in conditions like severe ARDS, where mobility is limited due to the inability to wean analgosedation or remove NMB usage (26). Allowing patients with conditions like severe ARDS to participate in PT is a major benefit of ECMO by limiting the known deleterious effects of typical treatments.

This study is limited by being from a single center and its retrospective design. The inability to directly control for and define illness severity as it relates to functionality presents a challenge in that there exists a spectrum of critical illness that may or may not significantly impact a patient’s ability to participate in PT. Presumably, healthier patients are more likely to meet the criteria for and consistently participate in PT. This, in turn, can limit the ability to evaluate the influence of PT on long-term outcomes. Within the limitations of our study, we attempted to account for this by excluding patients in our cohort who did not survive or remain on ECMO for less than 3 days. Furthermore, we only performed outcome modeling and analysis in patients who survived to hospital discharge. This attempts to address the problem of confounding by illness severity. Although this study was conducted at a single center, which limits its generalizability, it took place at a high-volume, tertiary ECMO referral center with a large catchment area. This enabled the collection of enough data for meaningful insights.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The mobilization of critically ill patients on ECMO is both safe and feasible, but it necessitates a team with expertise and adequate resources. In our study, there was an association with patients who participated in PT at moderate to high frequencies, and those who participated in PT while on ECMO, with improved functional outcomes at hospital discharge.

While our research adds to the growing literature supporting the feasibility and benefits of PT at moderate to high frequencies, further investigation is essential to establish a more causal link, inclusion criteria, therapy regimens, and effects on outcomes. Future research should include prospective trials that assess survival rates, length of stay, discharge destinations, functional mobility, quality of life, and longitudinal factors such as productivity in survivors.

sec.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sec.p: The described work performed would not be possible without the efforts and dedication of our multidisciplinary care team consisting of registered nurses, perfusionists, respiratory, occupational, and physical therapists, advanced practice providers, trainees, physicians, and surgeons.

fn.p: Presented, in part, at the annual meeting of the Society of Critical Care Medicine, Orlando, FL, February 23-25, 2025.
Support was provided internally by the Emory Department of Anesthesiology.
The authors have disclosed that they do not have any potential conflicts of interest.
